Interview: Process took about 4 months. Coding assesment(LC med-hard), psychiatric assesment, coding rounds(LC med-hard + production quality coding) and engineering manager round(In depth knowledge of jargons used in experience/cv). Finally the performance of all these round is reviewed by CEO/COO for final approval. 

Tip: Coding rounds are not generic dsa based rounds. You solve the given question, upon which you are given more extensions of the problems. Good coding standards are need to be kept in mind to easily decompose functionalities and extend the solution on new requirements. Be mindful of using jargons in managerial rounds as you will be taken in-depth based on what you say.

Eventually, I contacted candidate support with all the relevant details, and I received a call from the recruiter on the same day.

The recruiter mentioned that there was a delay because he needed approval to schedule the onsite rounds. (Can anyone confirm if this is a common situation ? I am not sure.) I asked for a tentative date for the onsite rounds, and he mentioned mid-August. The following day, he sent me preparation material for the onsite interview.

I waited until August 12th and sent him another LinkedIn message and email, but I still haven't received a response. While I am okay with the timing, I feel that there should be clearer communication regarding the details.

Could you please advise on what steps I should take next? Thank you in advance.

title: Beware of PolicyBazaar | SDE-2
content:
I recently appeared for an interview process for an experienced role at PolicyBazaar. 
My details:-
Education: BTech Tier 3
Current Company: Service Based
CTC: (Single digit in lakhs)
YOE: 2yrs+

Here’s a summary of what happened:

**Round 1**: Technical interview with an experienced developer.
I answered all questions in 45 minutes.

**Round 2**: Technical interview with a team lead. 
I solved the problem and other questions in 25 minutes. The interviewer was very impressed with my knowledge.

**Round 3**: Interview with the CTO. 
The interview got rescheduled twice due to panel's unavailability, and when the interview finally happened, it started abruptly with no introduction. He asked detailed questions without considering my experience and role which they were hiring for, I somehow managed to answer. When it came to discussing my salary, I requested a 50-60% hike, which is lower than what they typically offer to the SDE-1s. The CTO abruptly ended the call, offering only a 20% hike.

Before the process began, I clearly stated that my current salary was low and I was only asking for a modest increase. The recruiter agreed to this. After the interview, the recruiter told me I was rejected due to unrealistic salary demands. I pointed out that this was not mentioned earlier. In reply she said 'the CTO’s decision is final, I cannot change his words'.

Having no choices left I told her that I am open to negotiations.
Eventually, I agreed to a 24% hike. She hurrily took all my docs for offer processing. 

She then accused me of forging documents and claimed my last year salary hike was untrue. I explained that I had received a 30% hike due to being a top performer and has also recieved several awards and recognition emails in the past year. Despite this, she was skeptical until I provided screenshots of my appraisal and manager feedback emails.

Then again she didn't spoke for few days but after multiple follow ups she accused me of editing my salary slips, so I shared my bank statement  with her, next day she called me and dicussed the salary breakup with me. After that she didn't spoke again. I tried reaching out through mails and calls, later she blocked me.

This experience has shown me how candidates can be exploited. It’s disappointing to see such unprofessional behavior from a company with a big brand name.

Please think twice before applying for such companies, even if you get selected, you'll be exploited badly.

title: Microsoft | L62 | Bangalore, India
content:
**About Me:**
* Education: 2nd Tier(Startups consider it as 1st tier)
* YOE: 3 years

**Current Company:** 
* **Company:** an Indian unicorn startup
* **Level:** SDE-2
* **Fixed:** 29 fixed
* **ESOPs:** 6 lacs 

**Microsoft Offer:**
* **Level:** L62
* **Fixed:** 41.5 lacs including PF
* **Stocks:** 90k USD
* **Bonus:** 0-20% of fixed
* **Joining /Sign-on/Relocation Bonuses:** 0(None)
* **Max comp:** Fixed(41.5 lacs) + Stocks(~18.8 lacs) + Bonus(8.30 lacs) = 68.6 lacs
* **Avg comp:** Fixed(41.5 lacs) + Stocks(~18.8 lacs) + Bonus(4.15 lacs at 10%) = 64.45 lacs
* **Benefits:** Standard Microsoft Benefits: Professional Development(2 lacs), Insurances, Child care, Free cab & shuttle, ESPP(at 5% discount)

**Interview Experience:**
* Interview took place in May.
* Initially was informed that 4 rounds would take place. 1 DSA + 1 LLD + 1 Sys Design + 1 HM.
* 1st round: Discussion on current experience(10 mins) + 1 DSA problem with 2 variants(20 mins) + Again Discussion on resume(30 mins)
* 1st round verdict: HR only informs with positive/negative. not the degree(strong/normal/lean). It was positive from HR. My verdict: Very strong.
* 2nd round: 1 DSA(20 mins). Interviewer hadn't prepared 2nd question. I had to dug a pit for myself by coming up with a variant and coded.
* 2nd round verdict: HR: positive. Mine: Strong. Interviewer wasn't very engaging, round was only DSA oriented, so I didn't enjoy and felt as good as other rounds.
* Was informed 1 hr after 2nd round that now only 1 more round will happen for me. It will(may) be a mix of everything(behavioural + system design + DSA). 3rd round was scheduled 30 mins from the moment this call happened.
* 3rd round: 2 folks were there. 1 my future manager(I now know because he is my actual manager too in offer letter). And 2nd guy was also very senior EM like. Started with a bit about myself. Then they explained a bit about team. Discussions on my resume and past experience. Few behavioural questions like my mentorship skills, my conduct with my manager, potentially resolving bandwidth issues in case of juggling between teams. 5 min quick HLD discussion on URL shortener. A bit discussion about the team at last. Interview lasted 1 hour.
* 3rd round verdict: This time recruiter itself called and informed round was positive. My verict: Very Strong.
* All this happened on Friday. Got the email for details on Monday.

**Post Interview Experience:**
* Same day was informed that I cleared. 
* 2 days later details were requested. 
* 1st discussion on expected comp happened 2 weeks after interview. 
* 1 week after that proposed offer was verbally communicated. Was trying for more stocks but recruiter didn't buzz as L62 was already an out of bands offer from them.
* Accepted 1 day after that.

title: Am I lowballed by my new product company? service to product, not feeling good.
content:
Hi everyone,

I'm reaching out for some advice on a career decision I made.

Previously, I had a decent remote position with a service company in Gurugram, earning 23 LPA with 10 years of experience in the finance sector. Seeking better security, I jumped to a product startup entering the Indian market for a 34 LPA offer (29 fixed + 5 variable, specific to engineers).

The new company is in Hyderabad, and I was surprised by the high cost of living. Forget 2-3 BHK flats under 1 crore, builders just laugh! Rents are high too.

Starting in April, my salary dropped by 35k per month compared to the initial 3 months.

Now, I'm questioning my decision. While I had a 32 LPA offer from a service company in Gurugram, the product company's policies are concerning. They make frequent changes, and my manager openly discusses replacing European contractors with cheaper Indian hires.

The supposed salary increase barely covers the increased expenses in Hyderabad. Additionally, office politics seem rampant, with other teams creating drama despite my team being okay.

Honestly, with the pay cut and considering the same-city service company offer with better policies, I feel like I might've made a mistake.

What are your thoughts? Should I explore other options or try negotiating within the company?

title: 3L to 32L | Journey from Tier 4 to TCS to Oracle, ServiceNow, AlphaSense, Rakuten, Lowe's offers
content:
Recently I've been getting a lot of DMs after my switch. Decided to share my journey to help out this amazing community in these tough times ❤️

**Fun college days with no internships nor coding**
I was really into sports so used to be on the field all the time so these things never came across my mind until after I graduated. Best takeaway was a computer science degree.

**Debut at a Service Based Company**
Literally zero companies came to our campus. Somehow got a job at TCS and was really happy. Still unaware about leetcode. 

**Decided to prepare for a top product based company**
Started with Leetcode. Tried easy questions. Failed. Learnt all the data structures. Fundamental algos. Solved easy questions. Tried medium questions. Failed. Implemented all the data structures and algorithms learnt. Tried medium questions. Failed. Solved 3 and 4 point questions from virtual contests. Slowly progressing. Still after one year of this I couldn't solve a given medium question. Back to drawing board.

**Change of approach and focus**
I was doing a full time job also. I needed more hours everyday to prepare. Stopped everything. Focused on health and diet. Dropped sugar completely. Started leetcode again with a fresh mindset and energy. Got myself a digital pen that helped a ton. Every question I fail I'd retry in 3 weeks. Always kept a timer and always talked as if I was at an interview to get used to the pressure. Never viewed the topic before attempting a question. I want to be able to figure out if this is a Dp question or greedy. Followed this random guy Elite Code on yt he has these raw videos of him approaching unseen problems. Then learnt everything about backend engineering and honestly fell in love with it.    

**Applying, networking and linkedin suspension**
Everyday I'd connect with people from target companies. Was getting referrals but wasn't getting shortlisted. Possibly due to being from a no name college and service based company. Connected and requested more than a thousand people in hope. Instead I got suspension from linkedin because of spammy activity lol. This was like when the market was at it's worst.

**Change of approach and finally the breakthrough**
Somehow got the account back and changed my approach. Started to engage with people's posts with genuine curiosity and love for software engineering. Small things like commenting would help with visibility and good networks. Leveraged this, with trying to get names of the recruiter or HM and contact them. Even request follow up to referrer at  times. Eventually got interview opportunities with many good product companies and was able to pass all. Was able to get offers upto 32L. Yoe is 2+. It came to a point where I had to decline interviews from good companies, as I was already content.

**Overall essentials IMO 💯**
- Maintain a solid graph in your leetcode profile.
- Don't over or under-prepare. If you can solve 5 pointer LC questions and some of the 6 pointers, go start applying. That's a whole another game in itself too.
- Network as much as possible. That's the only way.
- See what people from these companies are posting about on linkedin. Engage. These insights will be your differentiators when the interviewer asks "do you have any questions for me"
- There are too many things to cover but keeping it short here.

Hope it helps. 

Edit: those who're connecting via linkedin rest assured I will get back to you sooner or later

Benefits: Salesforce benefits
Other details: No competing offers and laid off from the company hence my previous TC was 0

I got rejected from
Amazon (rejected in first round) - ghosted by recruiter
Microsoft (no update after 1 month) - ghosted by recruiter
Google (4th round) -> Great experience so far even i rejected!! So much i learned from all rounds. Happy Here
Coupang (6th round i got rejected after 1 month of interview loop :() -> heartbroken
Wayfair (1st round) 
ServiceNow (1st round) 0> Left interview in 20 mins as interviewer was not listening. 
Atlassian (3rd round) -> all went pretty good but was ghosted by recruiter (2nd try in 4 months)
Coinbase (1st round)


So i want to tell you guys one thing don't lose hope and keep on persisting inspite things don't go your way. At one point i thought this is an infinite and never ending loop. I was expecting coupang offer for sure but did not get and was also positive on Microsoft. Not sure on Salesforce but got the offer. Hence there is a hope for everyone. Just keep doing & take a break if you feel fatigued. The road is very long but you are not alone.

Outer image is this dude earns so & so. But actual reality is
1. Interview pressure. (just 30 mins before you feel numb due to expectation you set on yourself)
2. Handle things when you completely don't know the answer. How to pray that your current interview just finishes. Your brain has limits
3. You forget lot of things which you are capable of without interview pressure.
4. Sometime IDE not allowed hence typing manually on platform is overkill. Don't know what interviewer expecting.
5. Google expect O(N) not O(N + N) which essentially almost same but they reject folks based on double loop. So sick.
6. Gave couple of interview when my leg is paining and i was under fever. The show has to go on.

At the end i feel employer should have mercy and use common sense judging candidates. There is so much things going in preparation. Judging is easiest job. Performing under immense judgement is toughest job.

My family was with me in very tough times and they sacrificed a lot for me. I am not gonna forget and they are my first priority. Even as a failed person they accepted me and there is no difference pre and post this offer. I realized i had everything even without job. Family >>>>> Career

title: Reverse Integer LeetCode Problem Solution in Python
content:
Introduction:
Hello everyone! In this post, I'll be sharing my solution to the "Reverse Integer" problem on LeetCode using Python. This problem involves reversing the digits of a given integer.

Problem Description:
Given a 32-bit signed integer, reverse the digits of the integer.

Example:
Input: 123
Output: 321

Solution:
python
def reverse_integer(x):
    sign = -1 if x < 0 else 1
    x = abs(x)
    reverse = 0
    while x != 0:
        digit = x % 10
        reverse = reverse * 10 + digit
        x = x // 10
    reverse = reverse * sign
    if reverse < -231 or reverse > 231 - 1:
        return 0
    return reverse


Explanation:
1. We determine the sign of the input integer and store it.
2. We take the absolute value of the integer to work with positive numbers.
3. We iterate through each digit of the integer using a while loop.
4. For each digit, we extract it using modulo 10 and add it to the reverse after multiplying the reverse by 10 to shift digits left.
5. We update the integer by removing the last digit.
6. We multiply the reverse by the stored sign to restore the original sign of the integer.
7. We check if the reversed integer overflows, and if it does, we return 0.
8. Otherwise, we return the reversed integer.

Complexity Analysis:
- Time complexity: O(log(x)) where x is the input integer
- Space complexity: O(1)

title: NewRelic India Hiring | SCAM !!! | Avoid
content:
Hello Community,

I will share my bad experience while interviewing with **NewRelic**.
They had a hiring drive in last week of march where they invited people post resume screening and a mettl test(This itself was mixup of 2 MED-HARD questions along with basic CS fundamentals which are often seen in campus screening in India to be solved in 60 mins). **Recruiter(Contractor Camsdata technologies) already had discussed about the current ctc and expected ctc and mentioned that there is no upper cap for good candidates**.
Onsite interviews consisted of two techincal rounds[1 techno-managerial round].
To a bit surprise, the HM only focussed on behavioral aspects for the whole time and other person asked both DSA and Design(HLD) in one round.

After three days, they intimated that feedback is positive and asked for expected numbers. Here as well they made clear that there is budget and soon offer will be released. Next day they asked for the salary slips, and **no further update for next two weeks. After multiple followups they let me know that expected CTC is high and they can offer max upto a number which is less than even my current CTC. I rightway declined that.**

My Observation : They have recently started the hiring in India post their layoffs in US and here they are just assesing the market and salary ranges. They should have clearly mentioned that budget at the first touchpoint itself and not after taking salary slips of other company.

If your salary is in FAANG range, you may want to avoid this.
**Please share if anyone faced similar situation.**
Posting here in the comp section as this section has max visibility.

title: WFA startup v/s Walmart - delta of time and comp
content:
it is like bird in hand v/s 10 in the bush. 

i have an offer from a small startup and it is WFA, but 60L base and 5L perf bonus(subject to passing probation as far exceeding) and paper money that too will be decided how well I fare in 3mon probation. my appraisal will also be in Jun25 while they have twice a year cycle but didn't make me eligible for as a prorated. 

only advantage is WFA and somewhere I benefit from it given I have small kids and can take care of parents well who need some medical assistance 

on the other hand, there's Walmart, 
60L base
12 bonus
25Lpa yearly RSUs(3 years actually, but there are refreshers at Walmart every year, worth same as RSUs)
but would want me to mostly relocate or somehow ensure 2 days a week working. 

the bigger tangential angle here is of time-

Apr 1 is when I am pegged to join that startup, and Apr 1 is also whrn Walmart might barely roll any offer and peg my joining in mid of April. 

what should I do?
a.) accept WFA startup and resume on Apr 1, and basis how Walmart pans out, put papers? can the startup nab me legally or force me to serve NP before I can join Walmart?

b.) join startup on Apr. 1and basis how Walmart pans out, I negotiate with startup fot another 10L base?

c.) dont join remote startup at all, presuming Walmart will sooner than later indeed roll out an offer and make me join albeit all is verbal ATM?

other details:
teir-1.5(non top 7 IITs) grad
10 yoe
desig at startup - sde4/staff
desig at Walmart -
staff/IN5

apologies for unstructured post, typing from phone. can furnish more details as need be.

Going with WFA startup option. Reason: personal family constraints, because Walmart isnt 95L, it is higher 70s and higher 80s for 1st and 2nd year. I have small kids, and dependent parents, dont want them to be brought to a stupid city like BLR at this point of time.

title: TCS Hiring Drive at Electrinic City Bangalore
content:
I had litrally **worst experience** at **TCS Hiring Drive**.

Recruitment team called me before 1 week for F2F Interview with TCS & took all my details along with resume.
I got mail from them about time and place for F2F Interview. 

On 9th March 2024:

Time was 9 - 12:30 AM & Everyone were standing in line outside of tcs building.
Security Gaurd said HR haven't came yet so please stand outside. 

At 10:30 HR Came and I went inside. 

1) Everyone were sitted in line and the management was damn worst.

People with all tec & non tech experience were comming and there was no resume shortlisted round so everyone were elible which should not be like this.

2) I gave my first round. I cleared it. I answered 100% questions and all correct.
3) Begore 2nd round the management team sent me to one room where background verification takes place. After spending 1 hour over there. One member from management comes and tells me that i need to sit in some other room.
4) I went to another room and there were in total 4 people all from java background having experience <= 4 Years.
5) Then one person from management team comes and says all the person who are sitted here have not performed well in 1st round. It was impossible for me to digest because I have given all correct answers and interviewer even said that you have cleared this round. I told him I cant believe this , you might have got wrong information.  He said let me check giveme 10 mins.
6) After waiting for 30 mins, I went to my 1st interviewer, I asked that you said I have cleared my first round right. He said yes, but HR said that we are only hiring for 5+ YOE , I said then why to wste my and your time then?
7) I then took this thing and explained it to head of management team. He was nice, he listened everything patiently and said you don't have to worry and your candidature will not get closed.
8) I gave my 2nd round and then did background verification.


Tip: Never go to TCS Hiring Drive if you are confident on your skills. Take virtual or individual Interview rounds.

title: Schlumberger (PITC) Pune Interview Experience – Internship 2019
content:
Compensation during internship - 17k per month with hotel stay and office pickup and drop.
PPO offer - 9.5LPA (back in 2020)

Schlumberger gave a visit to my Campus for recruiting 3rd year Btech students as interns for different roles.  They outsourced the initial shortlisting to FirstNaukri.com and hence the first two rounds were taken by First Naukri.  

**Round 1 - Coding and Aptitude :**

Doable aptitude questions - Time and work, reasoning, couple of speed distance questions and other easy aptitude questions.
Medium level Coding question - only one - Mirror a binary tree

**Round 2 - Telephonic Interview :**

This was quite abrupt so be prepared for it before hand, I received the call outof the blue.
The Interview was more about getting a feel of how good I am at my communication, academics and a bit of evaluation of how good I sound technically.
I basically gave the interviewer whole picture of what I did in my 3 years of college, I focused on my participation in clubs and chapters, the workshops that I had conducted and other achievements of my college life.

**Round 3 - Technical Interview :**

After clearing the first two rounds I had a hangout call for the technical Interview.
I had a lot in my resume, so the interviewer was busy evaluating me using that only. He asked about my projects and other internships that I did, the challenges that I faced and how I overcame all the hindrances.
For others, the interview did ask them a lot from DSA, DBMS ( many SQL commands as well). (Yes, I was lucky that my interviewer didn't ask me these).
He asked me few questions like "Do you prefer Microsoft technologies or Google technologies?" I wasn't sure which one the company used so I gave a diplomatic answer saying, "It depends on the application and the better technology present at that time, obviously that can be found out by a little research"

**Round 4 - HR :**

The HR interview was also on a hangout call, it was also abrupt, I got a call asking me if I am available and had the interview call just 5 minutes later.
The HR interview was very casual, I almost repeated what I told the interviewer in the telephonic round.
The HR was friendly and we had a couple of chuckles until it was over.

Present Update - I completed my 2 months internship, did 3 projects while I was there, my whole team and manger were happy. I also received a Pre Placement Offer.

title: SDE II in Amazon Toronto - Potentially being seriously lowballed
content:
Hi guys,

I recently accepted an offer for SDE II at Amazon Toronto. I haven't been assigned a team yet but while talking with the recruiter and the someone from the offer team I got the distinct feeling that I was being seriously lowballed.

The lady from the offer team told me this is what the they offer SDE II's in toronto at the moment :

1. Base comp - between CAD 130K and CAD 140K (I currently make CAD 138K as a Tech Lead at RBC)

2. Total comp - between CAD 195K and CAD 215K 

3. RSUs - between 400 and 500

4. Sign on bonus - the difference 

I have 9+ years of experience working as a developer (I've worked in India, the US & Canada) - 4+ years of experience being a tech lead - and my highest level of Education is a masters in computer science from a mid-rank public University in the US 

Is this a fair market rate or am I being lowballed because I told them that I don't have any other competing offers right now (which is the truth because the market for well paying tech jobs is in the dumps right now in toronto - I haven't been getting any call backs from any other place - this and intuit were the only 2 places that called me back - and I got ghosted by the Intuit Recruiter midway)

I told her I won't settle for anything less than 160K-180K base and 215K-235K total but she kept telling me that this is the best they can offer especially because I got downgraded from SDE III during the interview process (apparently they'll only hire you if you're 50% better than the people they have on site)

 I have a feeling this ain't gonna go in my favor.

Would love some feedback from any SDEII's currently working at amazon toronto or who recently got an offer for this at amazon toronto.

What can I do to not get lowballed in this situation?

title: TCS typically follows a two-stage selection process for hiring new recruits:
content:
1. Written Exam (National Qualifier Test - NQT):

This is the first hurdle and can be quite competitive.
The NQT is designed to assess a candidate's basic skills across various areas.
The test format may vary slightly depending on the specific role and location, but generally covers:
Verbal Ability (e.g., grammar, vocabulary)
Quantitative Ability (e.g., mathematics, data interpretation)
Reasoning Ability (e.g., logical thinking, problem-solving)
Programming Logic (e.g., understanding of algorithms, data structures)
Hands-on Coding (may involve writing code for simple problems)
2. Interview Rounds:

If you clear the NQT, you'll be called for interview rounds.
The number and type of interviews may vary depending on the role and seniority, but often involve:
Technical Interview: This deep dives into your technical knowledge based on your education, skills mentioned in your resume, and the specific job requirements. You may be asked questions on programming languages, databases, operating systems, computer networks, and Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) concepts. Be prepared to write code on paper or a whiteboard to demonstrate your problem-solving skills.
Managerial Round (or HR Round): This round assesses your overall suitability for the role and the company culture. It might involve questions about your previous projects, teamwork experience, communication skills, and behavioral questions.
Tips for Preparing for TCS Interviews:

Thoroughly understand the job description and tailor your preparation accordingly.
Brush up on your technical skills relevant to the position.
Practice writing code for common algorithms and data structures.
Prepare for behavioral and HR questions using the STAR method (Situation, Task, Action, Result).
Research TCS and be able to articulate why you want to work there.
By understanding the TCS interview pattern and preparing well, you can increase your chances of success in the recruitment process.

Problem: Design a URL Shortener

You are tasked with designing a URL shortening service similar to Bitly or TinyURL. Your service should take long URLs and generate short, unique aliases for them. When a user accesses the short URL, they should be redirected to the original long URL.

Implement the following functionalities:

shorten(longUrl): Given a long URL, return a short URL. The short URL should be unique and not easily guessable.
restore(shortUrl): Given a short URL, return the corresponding long URL. If the short URL doesn't exist or has expired, return an error message.
Your solution should minimize the length of the generated short URLs while ensuring they are unique across all URLs shortened by your service. Additionally, you should optimize for fast lookup and retrieval of long URLs from their corresponding short URLs.

You can assume the input URLs are valid and follow the format of a standard URL.

title: Microsoft | SWE Intern | Hyderabad, India
content:
Dear LeetCode Community,

I hope this post finds you well. I recently had the privilege of interviewing for a Software Engineering Intern position at Microsoft, and I wanted to share my experience and offer some insights for those who may be preparing for similar interviews.

**Interview Process Overview:**

* Resume Shortlisting: 
 The journey began with the resume shortlisting phase, where my qualifications were evaluated to proceed to the next stage.

* Coding Round (Online Assessment on Codility):
The second stage involved an online coding assessment on Codility, testing my coding skills and problem-solving abilities.

* Technical Interviews (Rounds 3 and 4):
The final rounds consisted of two technical interviews, each lasting around one hour and 1.5 hours, respectively.

* **Round 1:**

		Duration: Approximately 1 hour
		Content: Array (LeetCode Medium) and Tree BFS
		Additional Topics: Java basics and variations in the Tree question
* **Round 2:**

		Duration: Approximately 1.5 hours
		Content: 6-7 questions covering Trees, Trie, Stack (Hard), Array, and Kadane's Algorithm
		Difficulty: LeetCode Medium and Hard
		
**Verdict:**
Received my acceptance for the position of software engineer summer intern (8 weeks) and location is Hyderabad with a stipend of 1lac+ per month and a relocation bonus of 1lac.

**Interviewer Interaction:**
Both interviewers were friendly and supportive, creating a comfortable environment.
They encouraged questions, clarifications, and provided hints when requested.

**Tips and Tricks for Success:**
1. Keep your introduction concise and focused.
2. Seek clarification from the interviewer if any part of the question is unclear.
3. Don't hesitate to ask for hints if you find yourself stuck during problem-solving.
4. Take a minute or two to organize your thoughts before responding to a question.
5. If you're unsure about an answer, be honest and communicate that you don't know, rather than attempting to fabricate a response.
6. Avoid any attempts to cheat, as experienced interviewers can easily detect such behavior, leading to disqualification.

title: Cleartrip Interview
content:
The interview was for SDE 2.
There were a total of 4 rounds ( 3 Technical + 1 Hiring Manager)

Round 1 -> Technical -> Machine Coding (2.5 hrs)
		Conference room booking. Using Java. Apply all the necessary OOPs concepts. The code must accurately handle overlapping bookings and reject if the room is booed for the time slot.
		Went good. 
		
Round 2 -> Technical -> DSA (1 hr)
		Kadane's algorithm, BST problem ( similar to least common ancestor).
		went good.
		
Round 3 -> Technical -> System Design (1hr)
		Twitter System design. 
		1. follow other users
		2. make a post
		3. like/unlike a post
		4. comment on a post
		5. reply to comments
		6. trending posts based on likes

Round 4 -> Hiring Manager (30min)
		Basic discussion about my background and the technologies I know, mostly based on my resume.
		
Offer received -> 27LPA fixed + 10% variable + ESOPs

title: Accenture Advanced App Engineering Analyst Thapar 2022
content:
**Accenture visited Thapar University Patiala in 2022 for the Advanced Application Engineering Analyst role**

Eligibility criteria included a BTech degree with a CGPA greater than 6.5. They selected a substantial number of candidates, totaling 42 individuals, including those from non-computer science backgrounds.

**The recruitment process comprised four rounds:**
* Three rounds of Online Assessment (OA).
* A final HR round.

1. The first OA round comprised six sections focusing on computer fundamental aptitude.
1. The second round included two coding questions, one at an easy level and the other at a medium level. 
1. The third round evaluated English communication skills, writting skills, reading and understanding comprehensions.
1. Fourth round was an Resume/Projects Grill + HR interview lasting 45 minutes.

The online test was conducted via the Metal platform and comprised **90 multiple-choice questions** across six sections, including English ability, critical reasoning and problem-solving, abstract reasoning, common applications, MS Office, pseudo code, networking security, and cloud. The overall difficulty level of the questions ranged from medium to hard.

Joining locations offered included Bangalore, Hyderabad, Gurgaon, and Pune. Initially, candidates were given the option to choose their preferred work location, but later, more than 60% were assigned to other locations not of their preference. The offer letters were issued late, on August 31st, with the first joining date set for September 26, 2023. The hiring process occurred in three phases: September 26th, October 15th, and November 24th.

**The compensation package offered a Total CTC of 12.59 LPA, comprising:**

**Base Salary: 9 LPA**
**Variable Pay: 1.89 LPA**
**Joining Bonus: 1 LPA**
**Gratuity and Insurance: 70k**

**Additional benefits not included in the CTC were monthly Wi-Fi reimbursement, a one-time reimbursement of 18k for WFH setup, an extra 20k for relocation assistance, and monthly outings and events.The Salary would be credited 2nd last day of every month.**

title: How to prepare a resume for internships for college students?
content:
Resume shortlisting is one of the most important steps in the application process. We often face many resume shortlisting rejections that discourage us a lot. Even if we are so talented and experienced, still we are facing rejections. I am going to mention the resume preparation techniques which could help you a lot:
1. First of all find a good resume template. Don`t go for the tabulated templates rather prefer single columns as they take care of the brevity of our resume.
2. Try to add numbers to precisely describe your work and achievements.
3. Don`t miss any heading like experiences, achievements, skills, etc, for example. If you haven`t enough experience try to mention your college positions like programming mentor etc.
4. Try to use the same date format in the entire resume.
5. While mentioning bullets or key points make sure to have a proper order,  alphabetical sequencing, etc.

title: Paypal SDE3 Bangalore || Disappointing experience
content:
Background: 10 years of experience as backend engg in product.
B.tech from Tier 2 college.

I had interview scheduled with Paypal last week and the first round was a general project discussion with the HM. He asked me in detail about my project work and then some typical scaling and design questions. He then asked a few behavioural questions. It was more of a fitment round. It went well and interviewer was very friendly.
I had then another 4 rounds of interview in a single day which was too overwhelming for me so I asked if it can be broken into two days. 
I had 2 rounds of interview on one day and another 2 rounds for the next day. 
1st Technical round: Interviewer gave a piece of code and asked to review and suggest if it can be better. It was about reading a csv file and writing into a db tables. We had a very detailed discussion which went for 1.5 hours and interviewer seemed satisfied. I would say, I couldn't answer all the questions but majority of them. Morever it was a very open ended interview with plethora of ways to answer it and I did well.
2nd Round: This interviewer just copy pasted a question of DP which unfortunately I had never attempted before. He didn't want to discuss much on this and simply wanted an answer. I tried to give a solution which was not optimal but then decided to write a code anyway. No suggestions from his side other than one which was absolutely wrong.
When I was left with 20 mins, he asked to leave that problem and copy pasted another matrix multiplication of diagonals sum problem. I saw it and quickly wrote a working code in 5 mins. He tried to find error in my code but couldn't. I then tried to rewrite the first problem but he seemed to have already made up his mind of rejecting which I could sense. So I couldn't finish it up. 

Got mail of disqualification from HR.  - _-
I am currently giving interviews in many companies but in one or the other round getting rejected. I don't know how much preparation is enough. For instance, I am trying to work on as many DP problems as I can but this one problem I just missed and wasted my chance.
How do you guys prepare and getting job offers?
What is the best way to approach questions which are medium/hard and you have never encountered them?

I am sick of getting rejected now and very disappointed in myself. Seems like living in an altogether different world post pandemic where every company has very very high expectations from the interviewee.

title: Tips and Resources for Effective LeetCode Preparation
content:
**Introduction:**
Greetings fellow coders! 👋 I wanted to share some valuable tips and resources to help you in your LeetCode preparation journey. Whether you're gearing up for coding interviews or just looking to sharpen your problem-solving skills, these insights can make your preparation more effective.

**Tips for LeetCode Preparation:**

	1. Understand the Basics:
		Ensure a solid grasp of data structures and algorithms.
		Focus on key concepts like arrays, linked lists, trees, graphs, sorting, and searching.  

	2. Start with Easy Problems:
		Begin with easy-level problems to build a strong foundation.
		Emphasize understanding the problem-solving process over speed initially.

	3. Grasp Time and Space Complexity:
		Analyze the time and space complexity of your code.
		Optimize solutions for efficiency.

	4. Explore Different Topics:
		Cover a range of topics, including dynamic programming, greedy algorithms, and backtracking.
		Prepare for a diverse set of problems.

	5. Consistent Practice:
		Regular practice is essential for mastering algorithmic problem-solving.
		Consistency is key.

title: VP ||  EVP ||  DIRECTOR || SR.DIRECTOR || GOBAL HEAD  ||  AVP || ASSOCIATE DIRECTOR
content:
Narsimha Rao Mannepalli, EVP and co-head of Delivery, Infosys, resigned last year and is reportedly joining Cognizant. His remuneration grew from Rs 3.4 crore to Rs 6.6 crore.


Roy, who resigned from Infosys last month and hasn’t revealed his future plan, earned around Rs 5.1 crore, which jumped to Rs 10.6 crore from FY20 to FY23. Similarly, Dalal, who is now defending a suit from Wipro, saw his remuneration going up from Rs 4.4 crore to Rs 8.9 crore during the same period. Lobo, who joined Tech Mahindra as its chief people officer this month, drew about Rs 2.5 crore in FY20, which increased to Rs 4.9 crore in FY23.


Gopalkrishnan Konnanath, former senior vice president and global head – engineering services and blockchain, Infosys, who joined Cybage Software as its president last year – also saw his salary jump from Rs 1.5 crore to Rs 2.9 crore in the same period.

Hari Raja S, former global salesforce practice head at Wipro, who joined as partner at Ernst & Young in August 2023, saw his salary grow by 65% from Rs 2 crore to Rs 3.3 crore in two years and become one of the top 10 employees in terms of salary drawn in FY23.

Even notable executives who were promoted recently, like Jayesh Sanghrajka as the CFO of Infosys, Aparna Iyer, CFO, Wipro and Shaji Mathew as executive VP and group head, human resources, Infosys, saw jump in their remuneration — doubling or trebling.

Sanghrajka saw his remuneration more than double from `3.3 crore to `8.5 crore in the same period. Iyer’s remuneration grew from `1.1 crore in FY20 to more than `2 crore in FY23. Mathew, whose remuneration was Rs 2.2 crore in FY20, drew more than `4 crore in FY23.

While Infosys had more than 120 senior employees posted in India who earned more than Rs 1.02 crore per annum in FY23, the number for Wipro was around 65.




Jayadev Galla, CMD of Amara Raja Batteries, took home over Rs 52 crore as compensation in FY23. That was about 1,872 times the median salary of the company's employees. Amara Raja Batteries heads the list of top 10 companies with the widest gap between CEO pay and median employee remuneration.

title: TCS Digital Interview Experience | On-Campus 2023 (Virtual) & salary breakdown
content:
There were 2 rounds for us 1st was OA(Aptitude+Coding) which was conducted on TCS-ION browser and next was Interview(TR, MR, HR) It is Digital so they require you to know Digital Technologies Search about them you will get to know them.

**Online Assessment**: This was first round which was divided into 3 sections also you cannot switch between sections. Also, there was sectional cutoff(One of my friend was not shortlisted for interview just because he was not able to solve many of verbal questions even though he had solved both coding questions).

Verbal- Believe me this was the toughest as it had only 10 minutes for 15 questions be fast in this round.
Aptitude- You will have enough time in this round i.e 35-40 min for 15 questions level of difficulty was easy-medium (check in pdf below).
**Coding Round**- This round had different experience for all as the exam was in batches, some had got very easy basic problem while some had got  DP based questions. also very important note TCS compiler is worst it might not work in last 5-10 minutes so try to complete and compile your code as early as possible.

**Interview**(TR, MR, HR): After OA results were declared after 1 week and I was shortlisted for an interview. It was on webex platform.  It was just one interview which had 3 interviewees TR, MR, HR which lasted for 30-40 minutes.

They took turns to ask questions Digital mainly requires DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES like ML, AI, etc. It is good if have a project in at least one and have basic knowledge about all . Many of my friends were asked questions on project/oops/ML like those who had projects in ML were asked in-depth about it.
NOTE the following pdf consist of all Question for 2022 batch for interview round(Guys this jackpot for you believe me 50 interview experience of my batchmate):
https://drive.google.com/file/d/1396SQGzhO5FY8sy4i3uD-02ytHE0qJoi/view?usp=sharing
But I had a different experience.
I introduced myself and then first TR asked technical questions he told me not to explain the project and directly asked me my preferred programming language which I said JAVA and then started asking me questions on JAVA, OOPS. Like what is an abstraction, what is the difference between abstract class and interface, and many standard java questions(GOOGLE TOP JAVA INTERVIEW QUESTIONS AND YOU WILL GET MOST OF THEM)?

**SALARY**
7lpa for digital candidates 
9lpa for innovators bachelors(iits and nits and iiits)
11.5lpa for innovators masters(iits and nits and iiits)

title: Optimization code in C++
content:
The code you provided is written in C++ and is used to modify the synchronization behavior between C++ streams (like cin and cout) and the standard input/output streams provided by the C Standard Library.

Let me break down each line for you:

ios_base::sync_with_stdio(false);: By default, C++ standard input/output streams (cin, cout, etc.) are synchronized with the C standard I/O streams (stdin, stdout, etc.). This means that operations on one set of streams affect the other. Disabling synchronization (sync_with_stdio(false)) can improve the performance of C++ input/output operations, as it eliminates the need for synchronization between C++ and C I/O.

cin.tie(NULL);: By default, the C++ input stream (cin) is tied to the C++ output stream (cout). This means that when you perform an input operation using cin, it automatically flushes the output buffer of cout. Setting cin.tie(NULL) unties cin from cout, which can improve the performance by avoiding unnecessary flushing.

cout.tie(NULL);: Similar to the previous line, this unties the C++ output stream (cout) from the C++ input stream (cin). This can also improve performance by avoiding unnecessary flushing.

These optimizations are often used in competitive programming or scenarios where performance is critical. In regular application development, especially for iOS development using Swift or Objective-C, you may not need to explicitly use these optimizations.
